Not attached to dharmas, not attached to non-dharmas;

If they are not bound to these dharmas, then they are also not liberated from all dharmas.
Why is it so?

All dharmas are unborn, unproduced, without intrinsic nature, neither one nor two, neither many nor few, neither limited nor unlimited, neither good nor evil, neither deep nor shallow, neither still nor agitated, neither attached nor detached, neither dharma nor non-dharma, neither with nature nor without nature, neither existent nor nonexistent.
Bodhisattvas who see dharmas in this way see them as not-dharmas, because verbal expressions are cut off.
Not-dharmas are dharmas, yet they do not destroy the traces of all actions.

They fully cultivate bodhisattva practices, do not regress from omniscience, understand karmic conditions to be like dreams, echoes, and reflections in a mirror, and all dharmas to be like illusions, yet they do not contradict the karmic retribution of causes and conditions.

With all-inclusive cognition, they roam throughout the ten directions, teaching and transforming sentient beings.

Understanding the meaning of compliance, understanding all dharmas, complying with the true nature, attaining all dharmas, complying with the firm roots of goodness, complying with the fulfillment of all vows;
Attaining the firm and solid dharmas, which cannot be destroyed by any vajra, attaining the firm and solid vows, and attaining mastery over all dharmas.

At that time, Vajraketu Bodhisattva, empowered by the Buddha's spiritual power, contemplated the ten directions, contemplated the entire assembly, contemplated the Dharma realm, deeply entered the meaning of the phrases and flavors of the dharmas, cultivated immeasurable minds, and with great compassion universally covered all sentient beings. All the great kings in the world, the Bodhisattva manifests his body and takes birth among them,
Taking up the honored and noble position of a great king, he is able to subdue all beings.
His mind is gentle and always pure, and he attains mastery over all beings,
Always governing the world with the right Dharma, skillfully following along with the joy of the world.
The Bodhisattva is born into a pure royal family and is always able to turn the Dharma wheel as is appropriate,
Far from all evil, he rules the country righteously, and the beings of the ten directions have no disagreement with his teachings.
The Bodhisattva is replete with the merits of form and appearance, and is endowed with profound and wondrous wisdom,
Firmly abiding without retreating, he is able to subdue all demons.
Always able to fully uphold the pure precepts, he is decisively established in the power of patience,
Eliminating all the poisons of anger, he is always able to cultivate the supreme Dharma.
Bodhisattvas fully practice the Dharma of giving, with food, drink, flower garlands, vehicles, clothing,
Anointing fragrances, dwellings, bright lamps, and such offerings are immeasurable.
The offerings made by bodhisattvas benefit sentient beings, always able to give rise to a vast mind,
With a pure intention and great joy, giving to the honored ones and the world.
Bodhisattvas are able to give up all inner and outer things without limit,
Their giving is always joyful, never for a moment having a regretful mind.
Bodhisattvas are able to give their heads, eyes, hands, feet, flesh, bones, and marrow,
Completely giving away all parts of their body, their minds never give rise to regret.
Bodhisattvas occupy the great king's position, pure, noble, and respected by the people,
With great compassion, they give their tongues to the masses, enduring immeasurable pain without regret.
The bodhisattvas dedicate the pure roots of goodness from giving their tongues to all beings,
Wishing that all these beings will be fully endowed with a broad and long tongue.
The bodhisattvas joyfully give their wives and children, their minds never giving rise to sorrow or regret,
And they also joyfully give their countries and lands, and are able to give their bodies without stinginess.
They give whatever is sought after, according to one's wishes, and give at the appropriate time without resentment,
Able to give up all that they have, satisfying all those who come seeking.
For the sake of the Dharma, they give up their bodies countless times, cultivating austerities and seeking enlightenment,
And they also undergo various sufferings for the sake of sentient beings, seeking the unsurpassed wisdom without turning back.
In order to listen to and accept the TathÄgata's true teachings, they give away their bodies without weariness,
Their inner minds filled with boundless joy, in order to save and protect all sentient beings.
Having seen the buddhas, the bodhisattvas, with a mind of kindness and respect, make offerings,
Benefiting and delighting, all complete, they are able to hear and uphold the buddhas' teachings.
They dedicate it to all kinds of sentient beings, wishing that the world may attain peace and happiness,
Universally able to rescue and protect all beings, forever enabling them to attain liberation.
The bodhisattvas are endowed with all kinds of retinues, their physical forms are upright and majestic, and they follow the teachings,
Adorned with wonderful adornments, they are wise, kind, skilled, and intelligent.
For the sake of benefiting, they give everything, and have never had a stingy thought,
Not seeking worldly wealth and benefits, they benefit beings and seek enlightenment.
Fully cultivating pure merits and virtues, they carry out immeasurable excellent practices,
Dedicate it to all kinds of sentient beings, and do not grasp at the characteristics of the solidity of karma.
Bodhisattvas are able to give up the position of a great king, the adornments of the capital and all the cities,
The inner and outer palaces, all the objects, the pleasure gardens, forests, and ponds.
For countless hundreds of thousands of eons, with the unsurpassed mind they practice giving,
Awakening the world, showing the other shore, in accordance with guiding and transforming the various beings.
When bodhisattvas see those who come seeking, they come from the worlds in the ten directions,
According to their needs, fulfilling their wishes, the bodhisattvas' great joy fills their bodies.
The merit of the bodhisattvas' dedicating giving, the tathÄgatas of the three times,
The ultimate practice reaching the other shore, the realm of the unsurpassed guides.
Bodhisattvas contemplate all dharmas, who is the one who liberates sentient beings?
For whose liberation does one go to such a place? Understanding emptiness, one does not abandon the giving mind.
Because the bodhisattvas' wisdom is dedicated, they seek the true Dharma by dedicating,
The bodhisattvas' dedication is of profound meaning, and they are unattached to any dharmas.
The mind does not discriminate any karmic actions, and it is not attached to the retribution of karmic actions,
Realizing that enlightenment arises from conditions, it does not destroy the true nature of dharmas.
Understanding one's own body and not being attached, the mind is quiescent and has no support,
Wisdom discriminates the nature of no karmic action, and one skillfully understands that conditions are not without karmic action.
Not falsely grasping at past dharmas, one also does not grasp at future dharmas,
Realizing that the present is non-existent, one observes that the three times are all empty and quiescent.
The bodhisattvas ultimately reach the other shore of form, and it is the same for feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness,
Forever crossing over all to reach the other shore, their minds are humble and always pure.
Distinguishing the sense bases and one's own body,
Seeking bodhi in these dharmas, all are empty and quiescent, unattainable.
Not grasping at the characteristic of permanence of all dharmas, nor accepting the characteristic of annihilation,
All dharmas are neither existent nor nonexistent, arising from the convergence of karmic causes and conditions.
There are no sentient beings who attain bodhi, all dharmas are completely extinguished,
The mind is not attached to any buddha-land, penetrating the three times as nonexistent,
If one can understand the true Dharma in this way, it is also like all the most victorious ones.
Although seeking again and again, nothing is attained, the practices of the bodhisattva are also not in vain,
Therefore, seeking all dharmas within conditions, not contradicting the path of all causes and conditions.
Distinguishing and explaining all karmic traces, wishing to purify all sentient beings,
This is the practice of the wise, taught by all buddhas.
Following and contemplating, entering the correct meaning, naturally awakening to the unsurpassed path,
All dharmas are unborn and also unceasing, also neither coming nor going,
Not dying here and being born there, deeply understanding all the buddhadharmas,
Penetrating the true nature of all dharmas, without attachment to the nature of dharmas.
Forever free from the illusory characteristics of dharmas, that person attains the wisdom of the buddhas,
Discerning and understanding the various destinations of dharmas, the destinations of sentient beings and the destinations of buddha-lands,
All the dharmas of the three times without exception,
The dharmas realized by the buddhas of the three times, all able to fully hear and uphold.
The dharmas spoken of in the three times, such dharmas are all not dharmas,
In accordance with the practice of all dharmas, yet without destroying the characteristics of dharmas,
The bodhisattva dedicates to sentient beings, enabling them to quickly attain omniscience.
Buddha's disciple!
What are the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's seventh dedication of universally equal mind in accordance with all sentient beings?
Buddha's disciple!
